Soon kids will think gorillas can, and this cannot happen. 0/5 stars a giant failure.

I have played every Mario Kart game since they started on Super Nintendo. This is where I am ending it.To be fair, this game does have some good levels and large selection of characters, but that does not count for this game's major flaws.What Mario Kart 8 did wrong:1. The minimap is not on the TV where it should be, it is on the gamepad. If you use the gamepad, you need to look down at the map to see where everyone is, by the time you look back up at the TV, you ran into a wall or something. Not to mention, if you are not even using the gamepad, you don't get the minimap at all. This could have been fixed if you play on the gamepad itself, the screen is wide enough to fit the game and the map side by side, but they decided that more people would like to use the horn for your kart instead of actually seeing what you are doing indicated by 2 tiny screens on the right side of the gamepad.2. The camera is just awful during anti gravity racing. It keeps making me want to play F-Zero where the camera stays behind you the whole way, this one just sucks.3. This is a disc-based game, they should have put as many shortcuts to certain parts of the game as possible. For example, when you get a really bad start on the 1st or 2nd race, you want to start the grand prix over. On this one, you need to quit, wait for it to load, select your options (loads during every transition and sometimes gets stuck on the character select screen because the disc can't find the character you want to select fast enough), select your options, select your cup, then wait like 30 seconds. In Mario Kart 64, you had shortcuts to everything during gameplay when you pressed start which was sometimes unnecessary because cartridges are instantaneous. Even if you play a download copy of Wii U games, the harddrives still take forever to load.4. The game's difficulty is not based on skill, they are based on luck. In this game, regardless of how well you play, the game will make sure to destroy you completely at the end just before winning a race. You could be in 1st place, get hit by blue shells, lightning bolts and red shells so 3 or 4 computers can pass you. Mario Kart DS and earlier never had that problem.5. Finally, there is no snaking, there wasn't any snaking in Mario Kart 7 or Wii either, but this game you need it. 15 players against you exclusively, you need some advantage to make sure you can still win after getting slaughtered at the finish line. I know that Nintendo made power-sliding based on a timer rather than skills in rocking the control pad and strictly being faster with the controller than others, but why compensate for people that can't do that? For the last 6 years or so, Nintendo has been bending over backwards for people who just simply aren't good at the harder games.***6. Also, reintroducing the coin system was a pain. Get 10 coins to go full speed, that is fine, but you lose coins way too easily and the computers usually take them before you can.***7. Also, the music is just not fitting for Mario Kart. It is like arcade music sort of. In arcades (that thing that died in the United States and was a room with 100's of cabinets of games and is popular everywhere in Japan), there is a lot of noise all around you that on your particular game except for like DDR or MaiMai or Beatmania, you can't really hear your game's music except for the drums or something. The song composition is just unappealing and doesn't feel like it belongs in this game. Also, I don't understand the freeform jazz or swing music.To be fair, this game is playable, but if you rely on skills you have learned in the first 4 or 5 Mario Kart games to win in this one, you will hate this game. For me, I put this game back in the box and put it with the games that will never be played again. I am not even looking at the Wii U until Smash Brothers comes out.I am sure that if anyone sees the score I gave, my review will not even be read, I will just get flamed because they don't like my opinion, but that is what a review is, an opinion and why I came up with it.
summary: I am done with Mario Kart. 3 bad games in a row.

reviewText: 6 years by golly.  6 long years I've awaited with baited breath for this fine sequel to that fine predecessor that was Mario Kart Wii.  I rushed my package from the door right to my Wii.  My hands shook so violently with the anticipation that I nearly took a doctor's prescribed pill to settle my nerves then i reminisced ever so quickly that such an act would render my finer acuities and reactions to a dullard pitch of unresponsiveness.  So I trusted my fragile psyche would handle the overwhelming overload of sheer emotionalism as I waited for the load screen to appear.But all for naught.  My Wii sat there perched upon my entertainment center spinning the disc a few times and then the big viola of nothingness.  I hit the eject button on the off hand chance I put the silly thing in upside down.  But nope.  after back in it went still nothing.  I dreaded that my Wii finally gave out after all those games of Carnival Games and Bowling.  So I put in Metroid and that worked.  Zelda too.  But each and every time I place Mario Kart 8 in there ain't a doggone thing occurring.  Heck, I even tried blowing on the disc old-school style.  Still it don't play.Anybody know why?  I tried reaching out to Nintendo.  As I sat on the hold line for 15 minutes I kept thinking over and over why Nintendo would even wait 6 years to release a sequel when all they really need to do is set a few designers down to come up with some more tracks and slap different colors on the side of the carts.  Not like these games don't just about make themselves with what little true innovation comes along and gets stretched out over 20years of this particular franchise.Either way I just hope they figure out what ever problem I'm having cause I hear there is a sequel to Super Smash Brothers after 7 plus years.
summary: Is mine broken or did somebody forget to tell me something

reviewText: The game is well done graphically, the visuals are wonderful, the new 3d style is well done again graphically and the fun factor is decent.  Compared to the awesome control of Mario U im still trying to get used to the controls in a 3d style as for me Mario will always be a 2d game regardless of how good the graphics are. In this game and Mario U they are stunning but this game is hard to navigate as it's damn near impossible to determine where you going to land....again I love the smooth controls and camera angles of Mario U.  The multiplayer is kind of fun, my wife and I tried to enjoy it but it gets frustrating quickly for the control/camera limitations I mentioned above.  Once again going through the levels together is tough and if you get a little ahead of the other player(s) it kills you all or bubbles everyone which is very annoying.  The next thing is the cat suit power up, its way to overused like in every level, where are the racoon suits?  If you die 5 times in a level you get the while tanookie suit rendering you invincible save from pit falls which this whole game is.....  Overall Mario U is all you need for a great new Mario game this one is a real dud, it tries to pride itself on nestalgia but fails and the levels range from easy as hell to damn near impossible again due to the 3d mess of the controls and camera angles.  Not worth 60+ dollars by any stretch.
summary: Bad camera angles lead to bad controls and becomes boring quickly.

reviewText: this game is pretty good not very challenging like the other mario game that came out on wii u. the whole cat idea is kind of silly i dont like them being cats i just dont like cats period so. some cool features like blowing on the mic on the gamepad to make things blow around and to complete course's. iv had this game since the 22nd of novemeber and iv never been good at playing mario but im already 3/4 done with the game thats how easy it is. i never came close to beating the last mario for wii u so that tells you how easy it is, this game is for kids like 6 and up. not adults like the last mario. my opion it sucks
Nintendo really needs to make a new ip. This game is beyond boring. Mario hasn't advanced since Mario 64. There's a reason this game didn't sell as well as the previous games.

reviewText: I was really excited about this game. It has all of the stuff from other games like Mario and his buddy with the mushroom. While it was fun, where is donkey Kong?! He hasn't starred in anything for years!!  Donkey Kong should have been there it doesn't seem fair 0/5 stars
Nintendo always had horrible party games, Look at Mario party. This is their second attempt at it and they did a bad job. This game is so boringbye

I had Wii party for the original Wii which was a blast and I was expecting the same fun with this iteration. But sadly, this version of Wii party for the Wii u just didn't seem as fun. The games are plenty and some are intuitive but the ingenuity and originality that I saw with Wii party and even Nintendo land for Wii u did not seem present in Wii u party. My sister and I played this just a few times and now it's sitting on the shelf and collecting dust. There was nothing inherent in the game play that brought us back so in that regards it seems to be more suited as a rental. On the plus side, you do get a Wii motion plus remote with the game which is nice if you don't have four Wii motes.If you're deciding between this and Nintendo land, I would say definitely go with Nintendo land, there's tons more originality and replayability. I'd only recommend this to die hard Wii party fans but be warned, this game seems to have a lot less content and allure then the previous version.
summary: Lacking the originality and replayability that the original Wii party and Nintendo land have

reviewText: If you want the real Yoshi's Island experience, you need to play the original from the Super Nintendo. Any system that can play this game has a virtual store where you can buy the original SNES game and download it to your 3ds, 3ds XL, or 2ds, it will also be cheaper.Yoshi's New Island starts off well enough with the first level, but you slowly start to realize that it was a rushed game. Assets are re-used and the most infamous of the re-used assets is a single track of music. With the exception of boss battles, all this game has is one song. The one song they use in all the levels is almost always remixed, but it is still the same song. The choice of instrument was poor, as it is mostly Kazoos. The game does not progress well, most of the levels are tedious or boring to play, and you will find yourself only playing this game just so you can see whether the end is any good or not. (It's not.) In some cases secrets are maybe a little too secret, I know secrets are supposed to be inherently hard to find, but this is not a 70 hour RPG, it's supposed to be Yoshi's Island.You would be doing anyone you buy this for a favor if you just skip it and purchase the original SNES Yoshi's Island from the virtual store for them. The original was epic, more imaginative, and just as adorable.
summary: Get the original SNES Yoshi's Island from the virtual store.

reviewText: "Arzest (fully known as ARZEST Corporation) is a Japanese video game development company that develops games for video game consoles. It was formed on June 25, 2010 by key members of Artoon, which was also founded by Arzest Executive Vice President Naoto Ohshima, best known as the character designer of Sonic the Hedgehog, as well as his arch nemesis Dr. Eggman. Arzest was also founded by key Artoon and Sega members who worked on the Panzer Dragoon series."Yeah...Don't let the adorable box art fool you. For some reason I'll never understand, Nintendo yet again handed development of a Yoshi game over to Artoon, makers of some of your favorite classic games such as "FlingSmash", "Pinobee", and "Club Penguin: Game Day!"Also the same guys who ruined Yoshi Topsy Turvy and Yoshi's Island DS.This game is a joke.The soundtrack. Just please, listen to this: [...]This pretty much sums up the entire soundtrack.The graphics, or "art style" is also a joke. Face it: it's not art, it's ugly.The levels could have been designed by a fourth grader. They are stupidly short, easy, and uncreative. There's almost no variety whatsoever. Seriously, this game makes the recent New Super Mario Bros. games seem creative.Even the control scheme is flawed. Yoshi's jumps are no longer satisfyingly cute and precise. Instead, his shoes (Yoshi has no legs in this game btw) just sort of fold under his butt as he awkwardly floats upward. The floatiness really hinders the game's platforming. The one good thing I can say is that at least you don't have to hold B to run like is Yoshi's Island DS.The story is lazy too, but that isn't worth going into detail about.Yoshi's New Island is one of the blandest 2D platformers you'll ever play. The original Yoshi's Island on the SNES and Yoshi's Story for the N64 remain some of my favorite games of all time, but this one is just bad. The 3DS is a fantastic gaming system with quite a few great games. I would recommend Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds, Kid Icarus: Uprising, Mario Kart 7, Animal Crossing: New Leaf, Pokémon X & Y, Super Mario 3D Land...maybe even New Super Mario Bros. 2.Just avoid this game at all costs.

This game was great in the graphics department and the music was brilliant. A beautiful world doesn't cancel out repetitive, bland game play. The fun bonuses from the original Yoshi's Island were gone, which wouldn't be an issue except they were replaced with nothing. That alone makes it feel as if this game was stripped of something that made it so magical when the first one came out on the Super Nintendo.The egg throwing was very annoying. The fact Yoshi takes as much time to prepare his eggs to be thrown slows down the game and becomes very aggravating.The game does attempt to shake things up by utilizing tilt control when Yoshi gets one of his vehicle powerups. These become difficult to control sometimes and at times makes you wish you could just use the joystick. It's a shame that there's a touch screen on the 3DS, but this game doesn't take advantage of it at all in any way. That would be a great use for potential minigame bonuses at the end of each level.Sorry fanboys, but this game isn't great. It is disappointing.
summary: A Watered Down Version of the Classic

reviewText: NIntendo is stuck in the SNES era. This game is not next gen. What's the point of having a gamepad if this game doesn't use it. Step your game up Nintendo.

I have been looking forward to getting this game for awhile and when i finally received it as a B-day gift i was disappointed.I think the difficulty of this game cripples it considering how hard it is from the get go rather than it gradually becoming more difficult.I have played previous games in the Dk series and although they have indeed challenged me they have also been fun,i am also not someone new to these games or to challenging games in general.I don't consider dying again and again in one of the early levels to the point where i don't want to be bothered with the game and feel stressed out to be fun and i also think it is a shame that you are only able to control Dk it would have been nice to have the option to be able to pick any of the characters considering that Dk isn't the most nimble character to control...In ending i will say that this game is gorgeous to look at but that is all it has going for it...In my opinion.
summary: Expect to Die again and again

reviewText: As a fan of the original SNES series, I was disappointed in the last sequel (Donkey Kong Country Returns). I felt it was tedious, not just for the young generation, but especially for the older generation. I remember being able to play the original snes series with my father, who is 59 years old, but sadly, this follow up is too hard difficult, and far to tedious for him to play with me, making the game less fun. I'm 17, and even I have to say this game is too much.When I purchased Tropical Freeze at my local gamestop, I was hoping it would be better than the last one, and boy was I wrong. I despised Return's wii controls, and they made it even worse for the wii u. I had to use a super guide just to beat the last game, which was no fun at all. But guess what? This time there is no super guide at all! Making it even more tedious! Great! Prepare to pop a vain!The boss battles require too much work. Whatever happened to the old jumping on the head? Or simply throwing a barrel at em? Did nintendo completely ignore the original classic trilogy? Where is captain K rool? That's like not having Bowswer as the main villain in mario. The new super mario bros game was also extremely tedious compared to its originals. There is no originality in the soundtrack whatsoever, unlike the first three masterpieces. The graphics are good, though they are not much of an improvement over the last game. Like I said before, there is too much going on in the levels. I cannot even get through one level without at least dying 5 times.I don't know about you guys, but I am sticking with the original games. If only nintendo would hire Rare back. Rare would know how to make a Donkey Kong game the way it is meant to be enjoyed. I may have enjoyed this game had it not been called Donkey Kong "Country."Message to Nintendo: When reviving a classic family video game franchise, make it simple so that everyone can play it, including the older generation for folks such as my father. Complexity does not equal a good game!

I'm a true gamer and have played since the 1970's.  I have to say this was one of the most difficult games I have played.First the good...The graphics are beautiful.  I felt like I was in the Caribbean or South Pacific when playing this game.  The controls seem pretty easy to learn and use.  I like that you have the opportunity to use all the characters through-out DK series.  The first three levels are fun because it's challenging, the graphics are beautiful and the music is great.Here's the problem-  it is suitable for all ages, but not playable for all ages.  You need to be a full time gamer that doesn't work to complete this game 100%.  I love how Donkey Kong evolved over the past 35 years into a lovable character; one of my favorite Nintendo characters.  The makers should have taken into consideration the age group and adjusted the difficulty.  I like challenges, but some stages are almost unwinnable to the average gamer.  The problem is that some stages have a tiny degree of error and you would lose several times over to complete the stage.  I was able to complete 90%, but that because I gave up on the 5th temple stage;almost impossible.  The fun factor went down because the degree of difficulty made the game frustrating.The controls are simple, but if you don't have fadst fingers; you will lose...alot.  Again, some areas you have about 1-2 seconds to react and think.  You will have to lose alot to know the pattern and move on.  My tween girls gave up on stage three so I traded it in to Game sTop for a good price ($32.00).  I like a challenge, but there is a fine line that the makers past.Disappointing!!!So hard core DK fans...don't hate and say my review is not helpful because you disagree like many of you in my God of War 2 review.  Fact is I know very few tweens in my neighborhood who can play this game and they play all the time.  It's a fact and TRUTH that this game is too HARD!

This game has to be the worst game i have ever played in my life, First of all, why is a Gorilla called Donkey? nice fail nintendo. Secondly the game play seems like something for a little kid. Gosh  i need to stop wasting money on stupid games like this

After Super Mario Bros. Wii U remake I expected more from it graphic quality and game design and difficulty. It's terribly repetitive and get boring real quickly. I sold this after 2 days of playing it, there was nothing redeeming about this game. Don't waste your time or money on this.

reviewText: Mario U is awesome, 3d worlds is good but this series of Mario/sonic Olympics is boring, stupid and does not need to exist on such a great console.  The gameplay is tired and boring, the concept is lame as there is so much more that could be done like bowser/wario/Eggman teaming up and having the selection of Mario/sonic characters in a great Mario U style platformer that would be awesome but this is a waste.

reviewText: I bought this game thinking that it was a new sonic game, until i looked at the case and saw a fat guy with a red hat. I broke down in tears because i wasted money on this garbage.

I loved the wii-fit.  I thought wii-fit plus improved on that.  But although the wii-fit-U has potential, it has more negatives than positives.  If you already have the wii-fit plus, I would NOT recommend upgrading.Positives:- You can save 3of your own "routines"- There are some new mini-games- The pedometer will sync to the game, and show a history of what you've doneNegatives- Many of the old mini-games are GONE ("big top" balance/juggle game, beach segway game, balance and catch fish, and others)- When you go through any of your own routines that you created, it is much slower due to having to hit "A" through a lot of messages and pausing between each exercise.  It's annoying and it really increases the time to do a simple set of exercises.  Plus you have to keep a remote either in your hand or close by.- I'm on my 2nd meter and the attempt to record altitude just doesn't work well at all.  I wish it did, it would motivate me to use the stairs more.- There is a problem when you replace the battery on the meter.  I've found others report this same problem on the Nintendo forums, so it's not just mine.  I had problems with my first meter, it would occasionally say the battery had been replaced (it hadn't)  and when this happened the wii-fit would consider me a new user during the weigh-in.  Not a BIG deal, just annoying and time-consuming.  But then that became permanent (it goes together with a message from the animated board "is it just me or have we gone back in time").All my data is there if I look at the graphs, but every time I do the daily weigh in I have to get all the extra messages for a new user!  And always do the intro-balance game ... never any others.  Everyday it wants me to set a weight goal (it wont remember the one from yesterday).  This is VERY annoying and time consuming to do every day.I expect this problem will become more common as other people's batteries get changed.Calling Nintendo was no help, they claim to have no record of the problem (though you can find questions on their forums back to 2011, and some very recent ones with it resurfacing due to the meter).The only fix seems to be to create a new user - which is VERY annoying.  I lose all my data back to 2008, have to open up the advanced options of all exercises.  I can't "just" recreate my exercise routines because some exercises aren't available to me as a new user.So before this major set back with making a new user, i'd have given it a 3 or a 4 star.  Worth it if you don't already own the wii-fit plus, or if you love tracking your walking within the game.  I regretted buying the wii-U just so i could upgrade this game, even before i had to create a new user.I can't give it one-star because I still am a fan of wii-fit in general.  So if you don't own any version of the game ... you don't have the risk of losing years of data, so it's worth getting (if you already own the Wii-U and balance board).I'm still holding out hope Nintendo fixes the problems - the game does have potential to be an improvement.

We bought this mainly for the remote but also thought the game looked like lots of fun.  The blue remote is great and I'm glad I have it but we really didn't enjoy the game at all.  We tried the Questions and Answers and it's a bunch of really short games that are hard to figure out.  Every game requires different controllers so you're constantly switching controllers.  Some require the nunchuck, some use the game pad and some don't.  I think it would be fine switching back and forth if the games were more than about 1 minute long and actually fun to play.  When you go from a game where someone is using the game pad to a motion plus controller it took us awhile to get the players set up again.  I didn't see any way how this could end up being enjoyable for a party because everyone wouldn't be able to figure out the controls for the numerous short games.  Party games should be much easier for people to understand, pick up and play or it just wont be fun for anyone.  I think we tried one other mode and also didn't enjoy it so we just gave up.  I've since sold the game and kept the remote.  You'd be better off buying just the remote separately or another controller/game bundle such as wii party u w/ black controller or Nintendo land plus luigi remote.  I'm shocked at how many 5 star reviews there are for this bundle!
summary: Games are too short and hard to learn for a party.  Overrated!

reviewText: meh

Worse Zelda ever. Nintendo needs to step it up or kill the series. They need to give this series back to Panasonic so they can continue to make classics. The CD-i series is clearly the best Zelda trilogy.

Yet another day and another abysmal Aonuma Zelda is defecated out upon our collective heads.Where to begin?Gameplay:1. Overly easy: challenge free gameplay that makes Celda Wand Wacker Teletubby Island (some erroniously refer to this game as "Zelda Wind Waker") gameplay come off like Ninja Gaiden in comparison. Seriously you will NEVER die in this game, not even ONCE, not even if you are a lobotomy patient!2. Items: No need to possess any actual skill, just go around and hack up some bushes (Eiji Aonuma's favorite gameplay element from LTTP incidentally) and collect enough rupees and you can buy everything that you used to have to search for (in the superior Pre-Aonuma Zelda's ie Zelda 1-4) in order to find. Just pay that stupid Ravio creature for it and you'll get everything from the hookshot to the boomerang with no risk at all to your character's health.3. Lame gimmick: which turns you into a wall painting, the true purpose of which is not to expand the gameplay elements of the Zelda series in any meaningful way but just another arrogant and obnoxious attempt by Eiji Aonuma to force his disgusting and deformed art style version of Link down our collective throats. The guy simply will not learn his lesson that the Zelda fanbase utterly rejects his chibi art style as well the Saturday morning cartoon presentation for Zelda. In the year 2013 we demand realism NOT sub par dumbed down graphics that appeal to the soccer mom and kintergarten set. We especially desire beautiful epic graphics and sophisticated art styles because we are paying for these expensive overpriced game machines to play these type of games on and we want to see some actual visual performance for our money. In anycase Aonuma doesn't just need to be fired by Nintendo, Nintendo should of never hired him to begin with.4. Recharge bar: for all the Nintendo fanboy whining about the dominance of the "dudebro" first person shooter (FPS) games dominating the world of videogames these days and arguably dumbing it down as a result Eiji Aonuma has ripped off this feature from the Halo series but instead of providing a shield for Link Aonuma has used HIS recharge bar newly added gameplay element to make the game even easier than it already was since now you no longer have to find magic vials or arrows while adventuring out in the world the bar just recharges automatically after you shoot some arrows or use an item such as say the lantern. Seriously Aonuma will not be satisfied until Nintendo allows him to add a dedicated "win button" to Zelda.-Continued pushing of Nintendo's politically correct LGBT agenda by featuring a decidedly homosexual character in a Bunny rabbit suit named Ravio. Ravio is a human character dressed in a bunny suit that helps your character Link throughout the game by offering him various "tools" (note the subconscious innuendo there)...Anyway I believe the proper term for this sort of sexual fetish means of dress up role play is called being a "furry" if I'm not mistaken? Whatever the case its incredibly sick and inappropriate for children to be exposed to a freak like Ravio in this sort of "E for everyone" style game. I'm quite certain Nintendo's featuring of this sick and unsavory degenerate character of Ravio is along the same lines as how the tobacco companies used to use the Joe camel character to push young children into smoking. Well Nintendo obviously wants to encourage young people to become homosexuals which doesn't make any sense since the left generally says such people are born and not made. In anycase creepy and inappropriate character design by Nintendo/Aonuma here and thats not a judgement of being anti gay or even anti furry it is simply a desire for cohesiveness and congruency ie a movie about Martin Luther King Jr. would not be at all served in it's contexual believability by having a white man play the part of Dr. King, likewise homosexual characters and furry fetishists simply do not belong in the context of a midieval sword and sorcery action adventure which The Legend Of Zelda always was, up until the moment that is the untalented hack Eiji Aonuma got involved in it's development. Now much like with society Aonuma has destructively turned Zelda into an "anything goes" free for all where trains, robots, homosexuals, furries and other inappropriate set pieces are placed in a game world where they simply do not belong.-Rehashing Zelda: A Link To the Past's overworld maps in order to try and trick the Zelda fanbase into believing that Zelda is returning to it's glorious form from the past, when really this game is just another Aonuma turd that would've been better off not being made at all.What Zelda as a series and game franchise desperately needs is Yoshiaki Kozuimi or Takashi Tezuka in the director's chair for it ever as a series to return to health.To conclude and re-state my own review title over again because its THAT important to say it twice...Eiji Aonuma is a cancer on the Zelda series and must be excised for the Zelda series to ever become well again.I rated this game a 1 star because to my knowledge it simply could not be rated lower in Amazon's system.
summary: Eiji Aonuma is a cancer on the Zelda series

reviewText: WHAT THE HECK NINTENDO!!!!!!!!!!I want to roll, but I can't!!!!!!!!!Instead, I just turn into a stupid painting.what the hell?!!!!!!!!!!!
I want my money back, i thought i was suppose to play as a princess. BUT NO! i was some elf guy in a dress. wtf?

I bought this game expecting to crawl through dungeons, open treasure chests, and rent weapons?! Yes, in this game you rent weapons instead of finding them (saves time but not rupees). Also, the big villain is an art maniac.  It's not enough for him to try to steal the Triforce, but he has to turn everyone into graffiti. Also, never use parallel worlds as part of the story line. They're a good idea in theory, but in use are awkward and never work. I guess I was expecting too much, I should have paid more attention to the 7+ age rating. Good for young kids, disappointing for veterans.

I enjoy the Professor Layton games for one reason--working out the puzzles. The dialogue is just something to weed through. But this games seems worse than the others. It's screen after screen of inane dialogue. I wish they would just make a Professor Layton game that was nothing but puzzles. I find myself not making it to the end of these games because I get so tired clicking through dialogue to reach the puzzles.

This starts off as a much better than average game, but the main plot sequence, including all of the side enemies and main enemies, main goals, etc repeats like 6 times with very little variation.  You don't even due anything cool to get it to stop, you just plod through while your characters largely say the same lines.I had to put this game down several times and walk away just to come back, because of how much time I had invested.  By the end, I watched the beginning of the ending sequence, and then just turned it off.I will recommend against anyone getting this, especially if you're not a completionist.
summary: Not a completionist? this probably isn't for you.

reviewText: it's okay i guess. only gripes are that there is no atb, so you have to pray that the bosses don't go before your white mage and put your team down like a bunch of demented dogs. and the fact that the girl with the blonde hair is kind of similar to Tina Turner: getting that ass beat on a regular interval and calling it love....

After Chapter Four, it constantly repeats itself until Chapter 8! What the heck?  I was tedious at best. The ending is only a shocker if you have lived under a rock for years...This is not the best that Square Enix has to offer. I have no idea why everyone things this is so good...Its not. Now, it is not a total failure ...but it is annoying.There are good parts of the game ...so it is not a total wash ...but I think they ruined it with constant repetition...I got to a point where I just could not wait for it to be over....and I put in 127 hours... reviewText: Slow to start. It took about 20 hours into play time to get vaguely interesting.  The game had a plot hole the size of the crater that consumed Norende village. To make this worst, you have to travel through five parallel worlds, all  with the same bosses. That's right, you don't just get to fight the boss once but actually five times. Hope you like repetition.  The only redeeming fact of this game is the battle system. The system is a traditional turn base system only with a twist to make it interesting. Over all this game is a one star "meh" game.

Gay marriage isn't a necessity for all types of games, but in a life simulation game, it should be expected.  It's disappointing that Nintendo chose to ignore the fact that gay people exist and also play their games.
I am a proud PlayStation gamer that wants to play video games, this game sure did not hit the spot. This game is nothing like The Last of Us.
